                                            By 
                                                    Jeff Greenfield


                                            By 
                                                    Rich Lowry


                                            By 
Jack Shafer


                                            By 
                                                    Neera Tanden


            By 
Nick Gass

11/12/15 08:05 AM EST
Donald Trump defended his comment during the debate that increased American wages would hurt U.S. competition in a global market on Thursday, adding that he had not even realized he had caused a stir with his remarks.
“Let me just explain. That was on minimum wage and it was how we're going to compete with other countries," Trump told "Fox and Friends" in a telephone interview. "They were talking about increasing the minimum wage. And whether it's taxes or minimum wages, if they’re too high, we’re not going to be able to compete with other countries."
Story Continued Below
During the debate, Trump also said that he would not raise the minimum wage.
"But, taxes too high, wages too high, we're not going to be able to compete against the world. I hate to say it, but we have to leave it the way it is," he told debate moderator Neil Cavuto when asked if he would raise wages. "People have to go out, they have to work really hard and have to get into that upper stratum. But we cannot do this if we are going to compete with the rest of the world. We just can't do it."
Taxes are "so high in this country," the Republican candidate went on to say Thursday, touting his tax plan "that is going to lower them greatly."
"That’s what I’m referring to, and anybody should be able to see that. It was very clear," he added, going on to reference an on-screen chyron that read "TRUMP DOUBLES DOWN." 
"And interestingly, this is the first time I’ve even heard, you put a headline about 'Trump doubles down,'" he told the hosts. "It’s the first time I’ve even heard about it. I just called in and I’m hearing about it now for the first time, so obviously it can’t be much of a story."
The explanation is "pretty simple," he added, noting that he is "talking about the fact that we have to keep competitive both in wages and you know the cost, and we also have to be competitive in taxes, because our taxes are so high that we can’t compete with other countries."
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Trump defends minimum wage comments
